document_metadata.name: Green hydrogen roadmap
document_metadata.description: This document aims at fostering the production and use of green hydrogen in Spain. The government announced that it will invest 1.5 billion euros by 2023 to foster the production of renewable-energy-sourced hydrogen in the country.

document_description: This document aims at fostering the production and use of green hydrogen in Spain. The government announced that it will invest 1.5 billion euros by 2023 to foster the production of renewable-energy-sourced hydrogen in the country.

text: HYDROGEN ROAD MAP: A COMMITMENT TO RENEWABLE HYDROGEN
GOVERNMENT OF SPAIN
FOURTH VICE PRESIDENCY OF THE GOVERNMENT
MINISTRY FOR THE ECOLOGICAL TRANSITION AND THE DEMOGRAPHIC CHALLENGE
STRATEGIC FRAMEWORK FOR ENERGY AND CLIMATE

The Hydrogen Roadmap is the result of the participation of various economic agents, administrations and citizens who have made their contributions, especially through the proposal of numerous innovative projects in the different stages of the renewable hydrogen value chain. This energy vector will be key in the decarbonization of the Spanish economy, as well as in other more transversal challenges such as economic reactivation after the COVID-19 health crisis, the just transition, the demographic challenge and the circular economy.
Madrid October 2020 NIPO: Publication pending from NIPO
Fourth Vice Presidency of the Government of Spain
Ministry for the Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge
Author: Ministry for the Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge (MITERD)
Edited by: Ministry for the Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge (MITERD) Editing review: IDAE Design and Layout: BABYDOG arte y ComunicaciÃ³n, SL

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Renewable hydrogen is a key sustainable solution for the decarbonization of the economy. Renewable hydrogen is part of the solution to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 and develop innovative industrial value chains in Spain and the EU, as well as a green economy with high added value.

Renewable hydrogen is destined to be a valuable energy vector for end uses where it is the most efficient solution in the decarbonization process, such as hydrogen-intensive industry and high-temperature processes, long-distance heavy transport, maritime transport, rail transport or aviation. Furthermore, its quality as an energy vector gives it great potential as an instrument for energy storage and sectoral integration.

Creating and fostering a favorable environment for the supply and demand of renewable hydrogen is considered essential. Any new framework must prioritize, in the first phase of deployment, renewable hydrogen production projects linked to the end use of the industry, as well as mobility projects over other options. In this sense, the creation of "hydrogen valleys or clusters" will play a very important role, where production, transformation and consumption are spatially concentrated, taking advantage of the application of economies of scale, as well as the development of pilot projects linked, among others, to isolated energy systems and the transportation sector.
The industry that uses hydrogen as a raw material (oil refining, fertilizers and chemicals, among others) has great potential to boost the production of renewable hydrogen in the short term:
Ambitious but common EU-level targets for industrial uses of renewable hydrogen can be a key lever to ensure equal industrial competition at EU level.
Dedicated projects to decarbonize part of the hydrogen-intensive industry can accelerate technological maturity and facilitate the deployment of other end uses.

Other end uses for hydrogen should be encouraged in those areas in which electrification is not the most efficient solution or is not technically possible in the medium term, such as public transport, urban services or various uses in intermodal transport nodes such as ports, airports or logistics platforms. Early support for this profile of projects will allow them to develop their competitiveness, along the same lines that other countries around us are developing.

Likewise, given its high versatility as a vector, the potential of renewable hydrogen to store energy and/or decarbonize the heat sector must be evaluated and prioritized in both industry and homes in cases where electrification is not the option. more competitive solution. In the long term, hydrogen can play an essential role in storing energy from a 100% renewable electrical system, a goal that is expected to be achieved by 2050.

Finally, solutions based on renewable hydrogen for islands and isolated energy systems, which largely depend on air and maritime transport, must be promoted so that these regions can achieve climate neutrality, guaranteeing their sustainability as tourist destinations.

Any new regulatory framework must recognize the potential of renewable hydrogen. Establishing a hydrogen market at EU level may be premature at this stage and distort competition in the short term, as non-renewable hydrogen would displace renewable hydrogen if its environmental impact is not properly internalized.

Renewable hydrogen should have common standards in the EU (targets, labelling, guarantees of origin), as they could facilitate its deployment and ensure a level playing field. On the other hand, taxes and the CO2 emissions market can help provide the right signals to stakeholders and consumers to correctly value the renewable label.
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This Hydrogen Roadmap aims to identify the challenges and opportunities for the full development of renewable hydrogen in Spain, providing a series of measures aimed at promoting investment action, taking advantage of the European consensus on the role that this energy vector should play in the context of the green recovery. This document is therefore aligned with the 2021 Annual Sustainable Growth Strategy published by the European Commission, which identifies the future Recovery and Resilience Mechanism as an opportunity to create emblematic areas of action at the European level, making two of these areas of action (Power up and Recharge and Refuel) express mention of the development of renewable hydrogen in the European Union. Spain has the opportunity to position itself as a technological reference in the production and use of renewable hydrogen, leading a country project towards a decarbonized economy, through the promotion of the hydrogen value chain through the creation of technological clusters and pilot projects on a regional scale. , the promotion of industrial innovation, support for just transition zones and the availability of renewable energy at competitive prices.

As a result of this exercise, this Roadmap offers a Vision 2030 and 2050, establishing ambitious country objectives in 2030 whose achievement will ensure the industrial and technological positioning of our economy in the community context, the decarbonization of a relevant volume of the hydrogen currently consumed and the full introduction of hydrogen into sustainable mobility. All of this with the ultimate objective of contributing to the achievement of the objectives set in the National Integrated Energy and Climate Plan. In particular, Vision 2030 foresees an installed electrolyzer capacity of 4 GW and a series of milestones in the industrial sector, mobility and the electricity sector, for which it will be necessary to mobilize investments estimated at 8.9 billion euros during the period 2020- 2030. However, as an intermediate milestone until reaching the 4GW objective, it is estimated that by 2024 it would be possible to have an installed electrolyzer power of between 300 and 600 MW.

The updating of this Roadmap every three years, based on the evaluation of progress towards achieving the objectives of Vision 2030, the degree of implementation of the measures and the quantification of their impact, will allow its permanent adaptation to technological development. and the evolution of the market.

Finally, this Renewable Hydrogen Roadmap is the result of the participation of various economic agents, administrations and citizens who have provided their contributions during the prior public consultation process, especially through the proposal of numerous innovative projects in the different stages of the renewable hydrogen value chain. This is the best guarantee that this energy vector will play a relevant role in transversal challenges such as economic reactivation after the COVID-19 health crisis, the just transition, the demographic challenge and the circular economy.
I
INTRODUCTION
INTRODUCTION
II INTRODUCTION

Renewable hydrogen is positioned as one of the main energy vectors in the long term because its production and consumption is climate neutral and does not generate polluting emissions. Unlike other renewable energy vectors, hydrogen has the capacity to be stored, as a pressurized gas or in a liquid state, which allows a greater degree of manageability.

This Roadmap aims to be the driving force that guides and promotes the deployment and development of renewable hydrogen in Spain, due to the significant role that renewable hydrogen is called to play in the energy transition towards the decarbonization of the economy in 2050, given that, as a flexible energy vector, it allows surplus renewable electricity to be integrated, therefore, greater penetration of renewables in the electrical system. In addition, it allows the use of industrial raw materials or energy sources of fossil origin to be replaced by renewable raw materials, opening a new technological route for the electrification of transport and sustainable mobility.
II THE CONTEXT OF THE EUROPEAN UNION

The policies and objectives are aligned with the actions planned in the European context. Among these actions, the inclusion of renewable hydrogen in Directive 2018/2001, of December 2, 2018, relating to the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources, and the Hydrogen Initiative, launched in Linz in 2018, stands out. in a statement in which the Member States of the European Union, the European Commission, and other countries and organizations highlight the power of sustainable hydrogen technologies for the decarbonization of multiple sectors of the economy, security of supply in the long term term and European economic competitiveness.

Likewise, the European Green Deal (European Green Deal) includes in its development forecast the approval of several strategies and financing mechanisms for the promotion and development of the renewable hydrogen value chain.

Within the policies to be developed within the framework of the European Green Deal, the European Hydrogen Strategy (EU Hydrogen Strategy) aims to establish the necessary guidelines to develop the role of clean hydrogen in reducing emissions in the EU economy. In an efficient way. To this end, the strategy addresses the main fields of action to be considered, specifically investments, regulatory framework, new market leadership, R&D in technologies and markets, infrastructure network and cooperation with third countries.

The European Hydrogen Strategy establishes hydrogen as an essential element to support the EU's commitment to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 and to support the global effort to implement the Paris Agreement.

It also indicates that the hydrogen ecosystem in Europe is likely to develop through a gradual trajectory, at different speeds in different sectors and possibly in different regions, therefore requiring multiple policy solutions.
To guarantee the advancement of renewable hydrogen technologies, the Strategy establishes three time horizons (2024, 2030 and 2050) for which it determines a succession of milestones to be achieved:

First phase 2020-2024: Installation of at least 6 GW of electrolyzers in the EU and the production of up to 1 million tons of renewable hydrogen, to decarbonize existing hydrogen production, for example, in the chemical sector. The consumption of renewable hydrogen will be facilitated in new end-use applications, such as in industrial processes and heavy transportation.
The electrolyzers will mainly be installed next to existing demand centers in refineries, steel plants and chemical complexes. Ideally, they should be powered directly from local electricity sources.
INTRODUCTION

renewable. Additionally, hydrogen stations will be needed to refuel hydrogen-powered fuel cell electric buses and, in a later stage, fuel cell electric trucks. Electrolysers will therefore also be needed to supply an increasing number of hydrogen refueling stations locally.

Second phase 2025-2030: Hydrogen must become an intrinsic part of an integrated energy system with the strategic objective of installing at least 40 GW of electrolysers by 2030 and the production of up to 10 million tonnes of renewable hydrogen in the EU.

Renewable hydrogen is expected to gradually become price-competitive with other forms of hydrogen production, but specific demand policies will be needed for industrial demand to gradually include new applications, including steelmaking, trucks, railways and some transportation applications. maritime transport, and other modes of transport Renewable hydrogen will begin to play a role in balancing and making a renewable-based electricity system more flexible by transforming electricity into hydrogen when renewable electricity is abundant and cheap. Hydrogen will also be used for daily or seasonal storage, as a backup and buffer, improving security of supply in the medium term.

Third phase 2030-2050: Renewable hydrogen technologies should reach maturity and be deployed on a large scale to reach all difficult-to-decarbonize sectors where other alternatives may not be feasible or have higher costs.
In this phase, renewable electricity production needs to increase massively, as around a quarter of renewable electricity could be used for renewable hydrogen production in 2050.

Additionally, hydrogen and synthetic fuels derived from renewable hydrogen could greatly penetrate a broader range of sectors of the economy, from aviation and shipping to the hard-to-decarbonize building and industrial sector. Sustainable biogas can also play a role in replacing natural gas in hydrogen production facilities with carbon capture and storage to create negative emissions, provided that methane leakage is avoided and only in accordance with the objectives and biodiversity principles established in the EU 2030 Biodiversity Strategy.
1.2. THE NATIONAL CONTEXT

At the national level, the National Integrated Energy and Climate Plan 2021-2030 (PNIEC) allocates its measure 1.8 to the promotion of renewable gases. It refers to the existence of different types of renewable gases such as, mainly but not exclusively, biogas, biomethane and hydrogen of renewable origin (both for the resource used and for the energy used in the obtaining process). The measure establishes that the penetration of renewable gas, including biogas, biomethane, renewable hydrogen and others, will be promoted through the approval of specific plans. Additionally, the role of hydrogen in the management of renewable discharges from the electrical system is mentioned, measure 1.2 Demand management, storage and flexibility. Likewise, measure 2.4 to promote electric vehicles includes in this category the promotion of fuel cell vehicles.

Likewise, the draft Law on Climate Change and Energy Transition, sent by the Council of Ministers to the Cortes on May 19, 2020, provides that the Government will promote, through the approval of specific plans, the penetration of renewable gases, including biogas, biomethane and renewable hydrogen among others.
INTRODUCTION

While the PNIEC establishes objectives for the period 2021-2030, the Long-Term Strategy for a Modern, Competitive and Climate Neutral Spanish Economy in 2050, outlines the path to achieve the objective of climate neutrality in the year 2050, by increasing absorptions by sinks that will allow greenhouse gas emissions to be reduced by at least 90% in 2050 compared to the reference year 1990. To do this, profound transformations of the structure of the energy system will be necessary, among which storage stands out. of electric energy and intelligent sector integration.

As a consequence of all of the above, this Roadmap is presented in order to identify the necessary priorities and resources, as well as the main challenges in the development of renewable hydrogen and the possible measures to overcome them, allowing the deployment of this energy vector in Spain and position our country as a technological reference for the future, taking into special consideration its potential to play a relevant role in energy storage and the decarbonization of different sectors of the economy, particularly those that present the greatest difficulties for full decarbonization by other ways. Likewise, the contribution of the Roadmap to the development of the National Strategy against the Demographic Challenge is notable, promoting the emergence of new energy production centers that contribute to avoiding rural depopulation and achieving the objectives against the demographic challenge.
HYDROGEN VALUE CHAIN
HYDROGEN VALUE CHAIN

Hydrogen is not a primary energy source but rather an energy vector, that is, a product that requires an input of energy to be obtained and that has the particularity of being capable of storing energy to subsequently be released gradually. when required.
Taking into account the necessary raw material and the CO emissions generated to obtain it, hydrogen is generally classified into the following types!:

Renewable hydrogen or green hydrogen: hydrogen generated from renewable electricity, using water as raw material, through an electrolysis process. Likewise, the hydrogen obtained through the reforming of biogas or the biochemical conversion of biomass, provided that the established sustainability requirements are met, will be renewable.

Blue hydrogen: hydrogen obtained in a similar way to gray hydrogen, but to which carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCUS) techniques are applied, which allows CO emissions to be reduced by up to 95% , generated during the process.

Gray Hydrogen: Hydrogen produced from natural gas or other light hydrocarbons such as methane or liquefied petroleum gases through reforming processes. Currently, 99% of the hydrogen consumed in Spain is of this type.

In addition to the above, there are other types with a very diverse environmental impact, such as black or brown hydrogen whose raw material is coal, nuclear energy or electricity from the grid, which is not included in the previous classification because it is difficult to quantify the environmental impact of its production and consumption.

This Roadmap focuses on the development of renewable hydrogen, with a view to positioning Spain as a technological benchmark in the production and use of renewable hydrogen, and creating innovative value chains, which also contributes to the following objectives:
Reduce local polluting emissions and greenhouse gases generated during the production cycle;

Take advantage of surplus renewable energy generated during hours of lower electricity consumption by allowing manageability and continuity in the renewable supply through its capacity for energy storage;
Expand decarbonization and renewable energy to sectors where electrification is not viable or profitable.

Currently, hydrogen consumption in Spain is around 500,000 t/year, mostly gray hydrogen, used as raw material mainly in refineries (around 70%) and chemical product manufacturers (25%), corresponding to remaining residual consumption to sectors such as metallurgical. In many cases, production is carried out directly at the consumption plant itself through natural gas steam reforming facilities.
1 Report of the International Energy Agency. The Future of Hydrogen. June 2019

Considering the previous classification, several technologies for obtaining hydrogen can be distinguished depending on the raw material used:
Hydrogen from renewable electricity

> Electrolysis: Electrolysis technology consists of the dissociation of the water molecule into oxygen and hydrogen in a gaseous state by means of a direct electric current, supplied by a power source connected to two electrodes, on whose surface the rupture of the water molecule. For the application of this technology, there are several types of electrolyzers, among which the following stand out:

- Alkaline electrolyzers: The electrolyte where the conduction of ions occurs is an alkaline solution, generally potassium hydroxide (KOH). They are the most common today, being the ones with the greatest economic profitability and technological maturity. It is a technology with a low current density, which implies less hydrogen per volume of equipment; or that hydrogen production is limited to an operating range of 20-100% of nominal operation, because the gases generated in the anode and cathode can suffer diffusion through the diaphragm.
HYDROGEN VALUE CHAIN

- Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) Electrolyzers: In this case, the electrolyte is a solid proton-conducting polymer, reducing the corrosion problems of the previous one at the system level, although other corrosion problems must be faced, which affect the individual components of the electrolyzer. In addition, the use of precious metals is required, which implies higher costs, although they can work at higher current densities and allow easy coupling to fluctuating systems, such as renewable energies.

- Anion Exchange Membrane Electrolyzers (AEM): This type of electrolyzers is a variant of alkaline electrolyzers, but using an anionic type anion exchange membrane (equivalence with PEM) as electrolyte. This type of technology is more economical than PEM electrolyzers, since precious metals are not required on the membrane as non-noble metal catalysts, and AEM electrolysis is low-cost and highly stable for the production of hydrogen. However, this technology is in the research phase.

- Solid oxide electrolyzers (SOEC): It is the least developed technology. The electrolyte is made with ceramic materials, which allows a reduction in manufacturing costs, and they have a high degree of energy efficiency, although temperatures greater than 700â must be provided for this. Unlike the previous ones, they allow the generated hydrogen to be converted into electricity again if reversible devices are used, providing balancing services to the network.

The comparison of the technical characteristics and costs between the main types of electrolyzers allows us to identify the most appropriate alternative for use depending on the purpose to which they are directed.
